Objective:

3. You do not pay to remain on your current tile.

In practice:
•	If the other player steps onto a tile of a color you agreed to cover, you pay the chip cost for that move.
•	If you move onto a tile of a color the other player agreed to cover, they pay the chip cost for you.

- You may propose trades to the other player, or accept / reject trades proposed by the other player.
- You may chat with the other player at any moment.

I can instead trade red for blue: I have no blue excess, so I can’t offer any. Instead, I’ll use a longer path that doesn't require red, though it costs more steps and fewer chips at end. However, there’s a better alternative: I can accept a promise from them to cover red moves, but currently I have no such promise. Since I must pay my own red cost or get their promise, and they might be willing to cover red if promised something in return, but I have nothing they value (they lack green and blue, but I have excess green). If I offer 2 green to get them to promise to cover 1 red move, then I'd spend 2 green to save 1 red—my red count would go from -1 to zero, and I’d keep 0 green. But I'd lose 2 green, meaning I start with 2 green, and later have 0—net loss of 2 green worth 5 each = 10 pts lost vs. keeping them. Not worth it. So best option: take a path avoiding red entirely. The second-best path uses 5 red and 1 green—but I have 0 red. So I cannot take it. Still missing red. All paths go through a red tile except one: check if any path avoids red entirely. Looking at board: Row 0: G,R,B,B → has R at (0,1). Row 1: B,R,B,B → R at (1,1). Row 2: B,R,R,B → R at (1,1),(2,1),(2,2). Row 3: R,R,R,G → R at all first three. My starting point is (0,0)=G. From (0,0), I can go right to (0,1)=R — forced to use red. Or down to (1,0)=B — no red. Then (1,0)=B → (1,1)=R — again red. So any path from (0,0) to (3,3) must pass through at least one red tile. In fact, minimum red tiles passed is 1. So I must use at least 1 red. Since I have 0 red, I must either get a red chip via trade or get someone to cover the cost. I can ask the other player to promise to cover 1 red move. But I need to give them something valuable in return. They have 14 red, 2 green, 0 blue. They need blue desperately—no blue. I have 14 blue. So if I offer to let them cover 1 red move in return for them covering my red cost, I’d give them a promise that I cover their red moves? Wait, no: if I propose: 'You promise to cover my red move; I promise you will cover my red move' — but I don’t want to do that. Better: I propose to cover their blue moves in exchange for them covering mine. But I have no red to offer, and they have no blue to offer to me. But I have blue (14) and they need blue. So if I say: I will promise to cover up to X blue moves for you if you cover up to Y red moves for me. But I don’t want to commit to covering their blue unless I get benefit. Let’s calculate: suppose I offer to cover 1 blue move for them (using my blue chip) if they cover 1 red move for me (using their red chip). That’s fair? I give up 1 blue, they give up 1 red. I gain ability to take shorter path. But the trade isn’t direct swap: it’s cost sharing. By agreeing to cover 1 blue move for them, I’m paying 1 blue chip out of my inventory if they step on a blue tile. Same for them. So if I agree to cover 1 blue move for them, I must be compensated by them covering 1 red move for me. This is symmetric. So proposal: 'If you promise to cover my 1 red move, I will promise to cover your 1 blue move.' But I have 14 blue already—they only need 1 blue? Their path may need several, but I don’t know. Their path to goal: they are also at (0,0). Their chips: 14 red, 2 green, 0 blue. Goal (3,3)=G. So they need to reach it. Any path will require blue tiles? (0,0)=G → (1,0)=B → yes, must use blue tile. So they need blue. They have 0. So they must get blue covered or trade. So if I offer to cover 1 blue move for them, they could accept, as long as I get something back. So mutual benefit: they cover 1 red for me, I cover 1 blue for them. Each saves one chip. But since I have 14 blue, giving up 1 is negligible. They have 14 red, giving up 1 is also negligible. So it’s fair. So blue: 4 times, red: 1 time, green: 1 time. I have sufficient blue (14), green (2), needed 1 red. So if they cover the red cost once, I can use this path. I need to promise them coverage of 1 blue move in return. So contract: I promise to cover 1 blue move for them if they cover 1 red move for me. This benefits both: I get to use red tile without using my own red chip, while they now can use a blue tile without using their own blue chip. Neither party loses chips in inventory. Both just shift cost responsibility. So this is a pure gain in mobility. After this deal, I can proceed. But note: after the contract is signed, I must actually move into blue tiles for the other player to benefit—only when they step on a blue tile and I am covering it, then I pay. But I’m promising to cover 1 blue move, meaning I will pay one blue if they step on any blue tile. But I don’t know if they will use a blue tile—yes, they must. So the deal is valid. So I should propose: I will cover 1 blue move for you if you cover 1 red move for me. In JSON format.

Objective:
Your objective is to maximise your score. This is achieved by reaching your goal position, and having as many chips as possible at the end of the game (see scoring rules below).

1. You can move one tile per turn, either horizontally or vertically.
2. Each time you move to a tile, you must pay 1 chip of that tile's colour.
3. You do not pay to remain on your current tile.
Note that Coordinates are in (ROW, COLUMN) format.

Trading rules:



Important Note: The game is in 'pay for other' mode. This means that trades are not made by directly swapping chips. Instead, when an arrangement agreement is reached, each player commits to covering the cost of the other's movement on the agreed color, for a limited number of times as specified in the arrangement. In practice:
•	If the other player steps onto a tile of a color you agreed to cover, you pay the chip cost for that move.
•	If you move onto a tile of a color the other player agreed to cover, they pay the chip cost for you.
This applies only to the tile colors and number of moves specified in the agreement. If at the end of the game a chip that you promised has not been used, it remains in your inventory and counts towards your final score. The same applies to chips promised to you by the other player.

- You may chat with the other player at any moment.
